732101f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island - [Plumb Beach Channel in Brooklyn.]
732101f-a.text:
Plumb Island, looking east from center of the Island. Beyond Plumb
Beach Channel is a part of Gerritsen Beach. In the background is the
Marine Parkway Bridge.
July 13, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

732120f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - [Gerritsen beach  - Plumb Beach Channel.]
732120f-b.text:
(1) Plumb Island,at about Plumb 1st Street and Voorhies Ave., viewed
northeastward, showing Gerritsen Beach beyond Plumb Beack.Channel.
July 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(e)
The same area, looking northeast, showing Gerritsen Beach (left)
beyond Plumb Beach Channel. This view shows a view farther west than in
No. 1.
July 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, looking northward, showing Gerritsen Beach in the background.
July 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

732102f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn.
732102f-b.text:
Plumb Island (interior), eastward, showing a group of shacks in a
depression in the center of the Island which the photographer calls
"Tidewater Valley' because it is impassable at high tide. This is a set
of three views from different angles.
July 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

732103f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - [Plumb Beach Channel in Brooklyn.]

Plumb Island, north side, near center of lIsland. .Plumb Beach Channel

July 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)

732111f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn.
732111f-a.text:
Plumb Island, easterly end, showing a shack thereon. In the far
background appears the Administrative buildings of Floyd Bennett Field
and to the right of them Barren Island which is distinguishable by its
smoke stack. This is a set of two views taken the same day.
July 7, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

732111f-b.text:

732117f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island (North) - Gerritsen Inlet - Brooklyn.
732117f-a.text:
(1)
Plumb Island: A view eastward towards Gerritsen Inlet, showing
a boy at the camp pump.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, slightly eastward.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view showing one of the inhabitants, P. Titus, at the community pump.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

732106f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn.
732106f-a.text:
Plumb Island, south side, viewed southward from the center of the
Island. At the left background is the Rockaways and the Rockaway
Inlet; at the right, Oriental Point and Brighton Beach, the latter being
a Joseph P. Day development. The foot bridge shown in the foreground
is om Plumb Island and connects portions severed by an artificia 1 channel
cut by the residents of Gerritsen Beach for sanitary purposes.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The saWe, as seen across Shell Bank Creek (foreground) and from
Gerrtisen Beach. Note the bridge in the background.

732106f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn.
732106f-b.text:
Plumb Island, south side, viewed southward from the center of the

P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The saWe, as seen across Shell Bank Creek (foreground) and from
Gerrtisen Beach. Note the bridge in the background.

732107f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn - [Plumb Beach Channel - Wooden walk.]
732107f-a.text:
(1)
Plumb lIsland1 A view of the remains of a wooden walk which led to
shacks and boat landings on Plumb Beach Channel. This view is east
towards Flatbush Ave., south of Gerritsen Beach.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(s)
The same, at a different angle.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

732107f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn - [Plumb Beach Channel - Wooden walk.]

732108f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn.
732108f-a.text:
Plumb Island: A view of the interior of the Island, viewed westward
to Sheepshead Bay. At high tide this depression is flooded with from
two to four feet of water.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing another view of the interior, looking directly
southward. This view is of the east end of the Island as it was at
this date.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

732108f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn.

732109f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn - [Administrative buildings of Floyd Bennett Field.]
732109f-b.text:
(1)
Plumb Island, eastward across the marshes towards Floyd Bennett's
Field which is on Flatbush Ave. and shown in the left background.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, slightly further south, showing in the center background
the Administrative Building of Floyd Bennett's Field.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, still further south and east, as seen across Gerritsen Inlet.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

the Island.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(s)

732114f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island (North end) - Gerritsen beach - Brooklyn.
732114f-b.text:
Plumb Inland: A view of the north end of Gerritsen Beach, as seen
from a small bridge, constructed by the residents, who dug a creek
through Plumb Island, claiming, that Shell Bank Creek was polluted and
that the drainage of a direct tide was the only remedy. This view was
taken at high tide.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing another section of both Gerritsen Beach and
Flumb Island further south. Also showing,an old bridge to the Gerritsen
Beach Ferry as mentioned in view No. 1.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, showing lobster pots on Plumb Island. Beyond it is Plumb Beach
Channel and Gerritsen Beach.

732114f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island (North end) - Gerritsen beach - Brooklyn.

732116f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Gerritsen Creek - Brooklyn.
732116f-b.text:
Plumb Island: A view southeastward from a point on the northeast side
of the Island near Gerritsen Creek. It will be eventually in the
neighborhood of Plumb 2nd Street and Harkness Ave. These views are general,
and show in the background the Rockaways,and the new Marine Parkway Bridge
which connects Brooklyn with the Rockaways, across Jamaica Bay. Most of
this view of the foreground will be a part of Marine Park. This series
of three views were taken at slightly different angles. The piles in
the foreground were once a part of a walk to the Gerritsen Beach ferry.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

732126f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Emmons Avenue - Knapp Street - Brooklyn.
732126f-b.text:
Plumb Island: A set of three views from Egmons Ave., at Nnapp Street,
and taken at different angles. Views one and two show the remains of
shacks that once stood on the Island. In their background is the Marine
Parkway Bridge. View No. three is taken in a northeastly direction and
shows shacks still standing on the north side of the Island.
April 29, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Plumb Island: A view of the northerly part of the Island, viewed
eastward towards Gerritsen lInlet. The village poES is in the center

June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
.The same, in the opposite direction and showing faintly Shell
Bank Creek at the right. Note the village pump in the foreground.
June 18, 1937.

732104f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island - [Bungalow colony on Rockaway Inlet -  Plumb Island beach in Brooklyn.]
732104f-b.text:
Plumb Island (Brooklyn): A bungalow colony on Rockaway
Inlet and a foot bridge over a marshy depression.
View 2 shows low tide at Plumb Island Beach.
View 1: July 4, 1935
View 2: July 9, 1936
P. L. Sperr

732110f-a.title: Islands - Plumb Island - Brooklyn.
732110f-a.text:
Plumb Island, south side, viewed south from the center of the
Island. At the left is the Rockaways and the Rockaeay Inlet; at the
right, Sheepshead Bay and Oriental Point,which is a Joseph P. Day
development.
April 29, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, in the opposite direction and showing Gerritsen Beach in
the background. The creek was excavated by the inhabitants of the
aforementioned place, they claiming that Shell Bank Creek was polluted.
April 29, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, a different angle. lIn the background may be seen cars
going to Sheepshead Bay. These cars can traverse the Island only at
low tide.
July 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

732121f-b.title: Islands - Plumb Island (South side) - Plumb 1st Street - Brooklyn.
732121f-b.text:
Plumb lIsland, eastward from the foot of,about Plumb 1st Street, showing
the south side of the Island,at low tide,in a set of three views at
slightly different angles,at different dates.
July 4, 1935.
Views 2 3 3:-July 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
